text: She _____ a new car last week.

options.label: A
options.explanation: 'Buy' is the base form, but we need the past tense.

options.label: B
options.explanation: 'Buys' is the present simple tense for third person singular.

options.label: C
options.explanation: 'Bought' is the simple past tense, correct for 'last week'.

options.label: D
options.explanation: 'Buying' is the present participle, needs an auxiliary verb like 'is' or 'was'.

grammar_rule.title: Simple Past Tense
grammar_rule.description: The simple past tense is used to talk about actions that happened and finished at a specific time in the past.
grammar_rule.examples: - I **walked** to school yesterday.\n- They **played** football last Sunday.

text: They _____ to the cinema tomorrow evening.

options.label: A
options.explanation: While 'go' can be used for future in some contexts, 'are going' or 'will go' is more appropriate here for a plan.

options.label: B
options.explanation: 'Went' is past tense.

options.label: C
options.explanation: 'Are going' (present continuous) is often used for future arrangements.

options.label: D
options.explanation: 'Goes' is present simple for third person singular.

grammar_rule.title: Future Tense (Present Continuous)
grammar_rule.description: The present continuous tense (to be + verb-ing) can be used to talk about future arrangements and plans.
grammar_rule.examples: - I **am meeting** John tonight.\n- We **are having** a party next weekend.

text: By this time next year, I _____ my studies.

options.label: A
options.explanation: 'Will finish' is simple future, but 'by this time next year' suggests completion before that future point.

options.label: B
options.explanation: 'Finished' is past tense.

options.label: C
options.explanation: Future perfect ('will have finished') is used for an action that will be completed before a specific time in the future.

options.label: D
options.explanation: 'Am finishing' is present continuous, not suitable for this future perfect context.

grammar_rule.title: Future Perfect Tense
grammar_rule.description: The future perfect tense (will have + past participle) is used to describe an action that will be completed before a certain point in the future.
grammar_rule.examples: - She **will have graduated** by June.\n- They **will have built** the bridge by next year.

text: He _____ in this city since 2010.

options.label: A
options.explanation: 'Lives' is present simple, but 'since 2010' indicates an action that started in the past and continues to the present.

options.label: B
options.explanation: 'Lived' is past simple, implying the action is finished.

options.label: C
options.explanation: Present perfect ('has lived') is used for actions that started in the past and continue to the present.

options.label: D
options.explanation: 'Is living' (present continuous) can sometimes be used, but present perfect is more precise with 'since'.

grammar_rule.title: Present Perfect Tense
grammar_rule.description: The present perfect tense (has/have + past participle) is used for actions that started in the past and continue to the present, or for past actions with relevance to the present.
grammar_rule.examples: - I **have known** him for years.\n- She **has visited** Paris three times.

text: When I arrived, she _____ dinner.

options.label: A
options.explanation: 'Cooked' (simple past) would mean she started and finished cooking after you arrived, or it happened at the same time as a very short action.

options.label: B
options.explanation: Past continuous ('was cooking') is used for an ongoing action in the past that was interrupted by another action ('arrived').

options.label: C
options.explanation: 'Had cooked' (past perfect) would mean she finished cooking before you arrived.

options.label: D
options.explanation: 'Cooks' is present simple.

grammar_rule.title: Past Continuous Tense
grammar_rule.description: The past continuous tense (was/were + verb-ing) is used to describe an action that was in progress at a specific point in the past, often interrupted by another past action.
grammar_rule.examples: - I **was watching** TV when the phone rang.\n- They **were playing** outside when it started to rain.

text: _____ apple a day keeps the doctor away.

options.label: A
options.explanation: 'Apple' starts with a vowel sound, so 'an' is used.

options.label: B
options.explanation: 'An' is used before words starting with a vowel sound.

options.label: C
options.explanation: 'The' is used for specific nouns. Here, it's a general statement.

options.label: D
options.explanation: 'Some' is used for plural countable nouns or uncountable nouns.

grammar_rule.title: Indefinite Articles (A/An)
grammar_rule.description: 'A' is used before words starting with a consonant sound. 'An' is used before words starting with a vowel sound.
grammar_rule.examples:
- A cat
- An orange
- A university (starts with 'y' sound)
- An hour (h is silent)

text: Mount Everest is _____ highest mountain in the world.

options.label: A
options.explanation: 'A' is an indefinite article. Superlatives usually take 'the'.

options.label: B
options.explanation: 'An' is for words starting with a vowel sound and is indefinite.

options.label: C
options.explanation: 'The' is used with superlative adjectives (highest) as there's only one.

options.label: D
options.explanation: Superlative adjectives usually require 'the'.

grammar_rule.title: Definite Article (The) with Superlatives
grammar_rule.description: The definite article 'the' is used before superlative adjectives (e.g., highest, smallest, most beautiful) because they refer to a unique item.
grammar_rule.examples: - This is **the best** cake I've ever tasted.\n- She is **the tallest** girl in her class.

text: I need to buy _____ new pair of shoes.

options.label: A
options.explanation: 'A' is used because 'new pair' starts with a consonant sound and is a singular countable noun phrase.

options.label: B
options.explanation: 'New' starts with a consonant sound.

options.label: C
options.explanation: We are not talking about a specific, previously mentioned pair of shoes.

options.label: D
options.explanation: 'A pair' is singular.

grammar_rule.title: Indefinite Articles (A/An) with Noun Phrases
grammar_rule.description: The choice between 'a' and 'an' depends on the sound of the first word in the noun phrase that follows the article.
grammar_rule.examples: - She is **a talented** artist.\n- It was **an interesting** book.

text: Can you play _____ guitar?

options.label: A
options.explanation: When talking about playing musical instruments, 'the' is usually used.

options.label: B
options.explanation: 'Guitar' starts with a consonant sound.

options.label: C
options.explanation: The definite article 'the' is commonly used when referring to the skill of playing a musical instrument.

options.label: D
options.explanation: An article is needed here.

grammar_rule.title: Definite Article (The) with Musical Instruments
grammar_rule.description: When talking about the ability to play a musical instrument, 'the' is generally used before the name of the instrument.
grammar_rule.examples: - He plays **the piano** very well.\n- She is learning to play **the violin**.

text: _____ information you gave me was very helpful.

options.label: A
options.explanation: 'Information' is an uncountable noun, so 'a' cannot be used directly.

options.label: B
options.explanation: 'Information' is uncountable.

options.label: C
options.explanation: 'The' is used because it refers to specific information (the one you gave me).

options.label: D
options.explanation: While 'some information' is possible, 'the' is better here to specify *which* information.

grammar_rule.title: Definite Article (The) with Uncountable Nouns
grammar_rule.description: The definite article 'the' can be used with uncountable nouns when referring to a specific instance of that noun.
grammar_rule.examples: - **The advice** he gave was excellent. (Specific advice)\n- I love **the music** they play at that cafe. (Specific music)

text: The book is _____ the table.

options.label: A
options.explanation: 'In' means something is enclosed or inside.

options.label: B
options.explanation: 'On' is used when something is resting on a surface.

options.label: C
options.explanation: 'At' is used for specific points or locations.

options.label: D
options.explanation: 'Under' means something is below or beneath.

grammar_rule.title: Prepositions of Place (On)
grammar_rule.description: 'On' is used to indicate that something is physically in contact with and supported by a surface.
grammar_rule.examples: - The keys are **on** the counter.\n- A picture hangs **on** the wall.

text: She lives _____ London.

options.label: A
options.explanation: 'At' is usually for specific addresses or points, not for cities.

options.label: B
options.explanation: 'On' is for surfaces or streets.

options.label: C
options.explanation: 'In' is used for cities, countries, and larger areas.

options.label: D
options.explanation: 'By' means near or beside.

grammar_rule.title: Prepositions of Place (In with Cities/Countries)
grammar_rule.description: The preposition 'in' is used to denote location within a larger area, such as a city, country, or continent.
grammar_rule.examples: - They live **in** Paris.\n- My parents are **in** Italy for a holiday.

text: The meeting is scheduled _____ 3 PM.

options.label: A
options.explanation: 'On' is used for days and dates.

options.label: B
options.explanation: 'In' is used for months, years, seasons, and longer periods.

options.label: C
options.explanation: 'At' is used for specific times of the day.

options.label: D
options.explanation: 'For' indicates duration or purpose.

grammar_rule.title: Prepositions of Time (At with Clock Times)
grammar_rule.description: The preposition 'at' is used to specify exact points in time, such as clock times, midnight, noon, and night.
grammar_rule.examples: - The train arrives **at** 6:30 AM.\n- We will meet **at** noon.

text: He is good _____ playing tennis.

options.label: A
options.explanation: We say 'good at' something.

options.label: B
options.explanation: We say 'good at' something.

options.label: C
options.explanation: The expression is 'to be good at' an activity or skill.

options.label: D
options.explanation: 'Good with' is usually for people or tools.

grammar_rule.title: Prepositional Phrases (good at)
grammar_rule.description: Certain adjectives are commonly followed by specific prepositions. 'Good' is followed by 'at' when referring to a skill or activity.
grammar_rule.examples: - She is **good at** drawing.\n- Are you **good at** math?

text: This book was written _____ Jane Austen.

options.label: A
options.explanation: 'From' indicates origin, but 'by' is used for the agent in a passive sentence.

options.label: B
options.explanation: 'With' indicates a tool or accompaniment.

options.label: C
options.explanation: 'By' is used to show the person or thing that performs the action in a passive voice sentence.

options.label: D
options.explanation: 'Of' shows possession or origin in a different sense.

grammar_rule.title: Prepositions with Passive Voice (By)
grammar_rule.description: In passive sentences, the preposition 'by' is used to indicate the agent (the doer of the action).
grammar_rule.examples: - The window was broken **by** the wind.\n- This song was performed **by** a famous singer.

text: If I _____ you, I would study harder.

options.label: A
options.explanation: Incorrect for second conditional sentences.

options.label: B
options.explanation: While 'was' is sometimes used informally, 'were' is grammatically correct in the second conditional for all subjects.

options.label: C
options.explanation: 'Were' is used in the 'if' clause of second conditional sentences to express hypothetical situations.

options.label: D
options.explanation: 'Be' is the base form and is not used here.

grammar_rule.title: Second Conditional Sentences
grammar_rule.description: The second conditional is used for hypothetical or unlikely situations in the present or future. Structure: If + simple past, would + base verb.
grammar_rule.examples: - If she **knew** the answer, she **would tell** us.\n- If they **had** more money, they **would travel** the world.

text: If it _____, we will cancel the picnic.

options.label: A
options.explanation: Needs 's' for third person singular in present simple.

options.label: B
options.explanation: First conditional: If + present simple, will + base verb.

options.label: C
options.explanation: 'Rained' is past simple, used in second conditional.

options.label: D
options.explanation: The 'if' clause in first conditional uses present simple, not 'will'.

grammar_rule.title: First Conditional Sentences
grammar_rule.description: The first conditional is used for real possibilities in the present or future. Structure: If + present simple, will + base verb.
grammar_rule.examples: - If you **study** hard, you **will pass** the exam.\n- If he **calls** me, I **will let** you know.

text: If she _____ harder, she would have passed the exam.

options.label: A
options.explanation: 'Studied' is simple past, not past perfect needed for third conditional.

options.label: B
options.explanation: 'Studies' is present simple.

options.label: C
options.explanation: Third conditional: If + past perfect, would have + past participle.

options.label: D
options.explanation: Incorrect structure for the 'if' clause.

grammar_rule.title: Third Conditional Sentences
grammar_rule.description: The third conditional is used to talk about unreal situations in the past (things that did not happen). Structure: If + past perfect, would have + past participle.
grammar_rule.examples: - If I **had known** you were coming, I **would have baked** a cake.\n- If they **had left** earlier, they **would not have missed** the train.

text: _____ you heat water to 100 degrees Celsius, it boils.

options.label: A
options.explanation: 'Unless' means 'if not'.

options.label: B
options.explanation: Zero conditional: If + present simple, present simple. Used for general truths or facts.

options.label: C
options.explanation: Incorrect combination.

options.label: D
options.explanation: 'Provided' (or 'providing') can mean 'if', but 'If' is most natural here for a scientific fact.

grammar_rule.title: Zero Conditional Sentences
grammar_rule.description: The zero conditional is used for general truths, scientific facts, and habits. Structure: If + present simple, present simple.
grammar_rule.examples: - If you **freeze** water, it **turns** into ice.\n- Plants **die** if they **don't get** enough water.

text: I would go to the party _____ I wasn't so tired.

options.label: A
options.explanation: This forms a second conditional sentence expressing a hypothetical situation.

options.label: B
options.explanation: 'Unless I wasn't so tired' would mean 'if I was so tired', which is illogical here.

options.label: C
options.explanation: 'Whether' introduces alternatives.

options.label: D
options.explanation: 'In case' refers to taking precautions.

grammar_rule.title: Second Conditional (Hypothetical Present/Future)
grammar_rule.description: The second conditional (If + past simple, would + base verb) is used for unlikely or imaginary situations in the present or future.
grammar_rule.examples: - If I **won** the lottery, I **would buy** a house.\n- She **would travel** more if she **had** more time.

text: You _____ smoke in the hospital; it's forbidden.

options.label: A
options.explanation: 'Can' expresses ability or permission, not prohibition.

options.label: B
options.explanation: 'May' expresses possibility or formal permission, not strong prohibition.

options.label: C
options.explanation: 'Must not' (or mustn't) expresses strong prohibition.

options.label: D
options.explanation: 'Should not' gives advice or recommendation, but 'must not' is stronger for rules/laws.

grammar_rule.title: Modal Verbs (Must Not - Prohibition)
grammar_rule.description: 'Must not' (mustn't) is used to express that something is prohibited or not allowed.
grammar_rule.examples: - You **must not** cheat on the exam.\n- Visitors **must not** feed the animals.

text: She _____ speak four languages fluently.

options.label: A
options.explanation: 'Must' expresses obligation or strong belief.

options.label: B
options.explanation: 'Can' expresses ability.

options.label: C
options.explanation: 'Should' expresses advice or recommendation.

options.label: D
options.explanation: 'Might' expresses possibility.

grammar_rule.title: Modal Verbs (Can - Ability)
grammar_rule.description: 'Can' is used to express ability or capability to do something.
grammar_rule.examples: - I **can** swim.\n- He **can** play the guitar.

text: You _____ see a doctor if you are feeling unwell.

options.label: A
options.explanation: While possible, 'should' is better for advice.

options.label: B
options.explanation: 'Must' is strong obligation, perhaps too strong here.

options.label: C
options.explanation: 'Should' is used to give advice or make a recommendation.

options.label: D
options.explanation: 'Would' is used for hypothetical situations or politeness.

grammar_rule.title: Modal Verbs (Should - Advice)
grammar_rule.description: 'Should' is used to give advice, make recommendations, or express what is considered the right thing to do.
grammar_rule.examples: - You **should** apologize.\n- We **should** leave early to avoid traffic.

text: _____ I borrow your pen, please?

options.label: A
options.explanation: 'Must I' is very strong, almost a demand.

options.label: B
options.explanation: 'Should I' asks for advice about obligation.

options.label: C
options.explanation: 'May I' is a polite way to ask for permission. 'Can I' is also common but slightly less formal.

options.label: D
options.explanation: 'Will I' is about future, not permission in this context.

grammar_rule.title: Modal Verbs (May/Can - Permission)
grammar_rule.description: 'May' is often used to ask for permission formally. 'Can' is also used, especially in informal contexts.
grammar_rule.examples: - **May** I use your phone?\n- **Can** I sit here?

text: It _____ rain later, so take an umbrella.

options.label: A
options.explanation: 'Must' expresses certainty or strong obligation.

options.label: B
options.explanation: 'Can' expresses general possibility or ability, but 'might' or 'may' are better for specific future possibility.

options.label: C
options.explanation: 'Might' (or 'may') expresses possibility about a future event.

options.label: D
options.explanation: 'Should' expresses advice.

grammar_rule.title: Modal Verbs (Might/May - Possibility)
grammar_rule.description: 'Might' and 'may' are used to express possibility, often about future events. 'Might' can sometimes suggest a slightly lower probability than 'may'.
grammar_rule.examples: - He **might** be late.\n- We **may** go to the beach tomorrow.
